Morgan Byers

morgan.byers@colorado.edu
Department Of Computer Science
University of Colorado, Boulder

About Me

I am currently a second-year MS student studying computer science at the University of Colorado. In 2021 I recieved my Bachelor of Science in computer science and mathematics from Texas State University. My undergraduate thesis was entitled, "The Hidden Shape of Data: Topological Data Analysis for Anxiety Detection in Text," and can be accessed online via the Texas State honors program online thesis library.

Very broadly, my research interests lie in the area of topological data analysis (TDA) for time-evolving metric spaces. A deeper description of my research can be found under my Portfolio section. I am currently applying for the NSF graduate research fellowship. After completing my Masters degree I plan to continue on to a Ph.D., likely also from the University of Colorado.

While I was at Texas State, I also had the privilege of being the Digital Product Developer for the student-lead newspaper, The University Star . In this role, I oversaw the management of all of The Star's digital assets, including the management and design of the website and app. I assisted with overhauling the Star's website and ensuring that the new site was WCAG 2.0 compliant. In spring 2021, I earned second place in overall web design at the Texas Intercollegiate Press Association (TIPA).

I enjoy spending any free time I have as far away from technology as possible. My hobbies include reading (especially high fantasy), watercolor, hiking, and trying out new baking recipes. A fun fact about myself is that I can recite the first fourty one digits of pi from memory.

Portfolio

While I am not very good at keeping it up to date, you can find portions of my code on my Github. If you are looking for the code that corresponds to a particular paper of mine, check my publications section below. When applicable, I will include links to the repository where you can find code corresponding to each of my works.

I spent most of my undergraduate career working on projects for class or for my work at the IMICS lab. If you are a Texas State student or faculty member, you may access the work that I did on behalf of Texas State here.

Publications

For the most up-to-date list of my work, you can refer to my Google Scholar page.
